markup.content: Hi, I’m Beth. I’m here to guide you through the City of Detroit's website.
During our chat, you can close the chat window if you need to start again.
Ready? Let’s get started.
How can I help you today?
It seems you are looking to pay something. You can visit our payment portal to get started.
Visit the City of Detroit Payment Portal.
COVID-19 Self-Checker is intended for people currently located in the City of Detroit
Please check the Center for Disease Control and Prevention for more information about COVID-19 in your location.
Visit CDC Website
Are you ill, or caring for someone who is ill?
Sounds like you or the person you are caring are feeling ok.
Please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus website for more the most recent updates.
Visit City of Detroit Website
What is your (their) age? Please enter the number of years.
If you are filling this for a person under 1 year old. Just enter 0.
Are they experiencing any of the following lifethreatening symptoms?

items.name: no-waking
items.description: Not waking up or not interacting when awake
items.text: Not waking up or not interacting when awake

items.name: irritable
items.description: So irritable that the child does not want to be held
items.text: So irritable that the child does not want to be held

markup.content: Call 911 – You may be having a medical emergency.
Sorry, this Coronavirus SelfChecker is for people who are at least 2 years old.
What is your (their) gender?
Are you (they) experiencing any of the following lifethreatening symptoms?

items.name: breath
items.description: Gasping for air or cannot talk without catching your breath (extremely difficult breathing)
items.text: Gasping for air or cannot talk without catching your breath (extremely difficult breathing)

items.name: pain
items.description: Severe and constant pain or pressure in the chest
items.text: Severe and constant pain or pressure in the chest

items.name: dizziness
items.description: Severe and constant dizziness or lightheadedness
items.text: Severe and constant dizziness or lightheadedness

items.name: unconscious
items.description: Unconscious or very difficult to wake up
items.text: Unconscious or very difficult to wake up

items.name: seizures
items.description: New seizure or seizures that won’t stop
items.text: New seizure or seizures that won’t stop

items.name: breathing
items.description: Moderate to severe difficulty breathing (unable to speak full sentences)
items.text: Moderate to severe difficulty breathing (unable to speak full sentences)

items.name: cough
items.description: Coughing up blood (more than about 1 teaspoon)
items.text: Coughing up blood (more than about 1 teaspoon)

items.description: Signs of low blood pressure (feeling cold, pale, clammy skin, light-headed, too weak to stand)
items.text: Signs of low blood pressure (feeling cold, pale, clammy skin, light-headed, too weak to stand)

items.name: ribs
items.description: Ribs are pulling in with each breath (retractions)

markup.content: Urgent medical attention maybe needed. Please go to the Emergency Department.
In the two weeks before you (they) felt sick, did you (they):
Have contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19
or
Live in or visit a place where COVID-19 is spreading
Do you (they) have any of the following? (Check any)
Do you (they) live in a long-term care facility or nursing home?
Contact a healthcare provider in the long-term care facility where you live
If you don't have a doctor or are uninsured. Visit the City of Detroit's website to find a doctor near you.

In the last two weeks have you (they) worked or volunteered in a hospital, emergency room, clinic, medical office, long-term care facility or nursing home, ambulance service, first responder services, or any health care setting or taken care of patients as a student or part of your work?
Stay home and take care of yourself in home isolation. Call a medical provider within 24 hours.
Contact the occupational health provider at your workplace immediately

Welcome to the COVID-19 Resources section.
During the assessment, you can refresh the page if you need to start again or close the chat window.
Ready? Let’s get started.
What resources are you looking for?
What kind of food resources?
Free Meals for Children (up to 18 years old)

The Parks and Recreation Division of the General Services Department is providing meals for children at participating recreation centers. Parents and children may pick up multiple meals to suit their needs. Meals are offered, Monday–Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 1:30 p.m. at these locations:

content.content: Adams Butzel Family Center, 10500 Lyndon
Farwell Recreation Center, 2711 Outer Dr E
Kemeny Recreation Center, 2260 S. Fort St.
Patton Recreation Center, 2301 Woodmere (starting March 30)

markup.content: These additional recreation centers will offer meal pick up on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday from 8:30 a.m. – 1:30 p.m.

content.content: Crowell Recreation Center, 16630 Lahser
Lasky Recreation Center, 13200 Fenelon

markup.content: To Find out more about the food programs available please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus Resources page.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus Resources page.
Meals for Seniors

The Detroit Area Agency on Aging (DAAA) is providing frozen meals for seniors ages 60 and up. Seniors can pick up five days worth of meals every Wednesday from 11:30 a.m. – 1:00 p.m. at the following recreation centers:

content.content: Adams Butzel Family Center, 10500 Lyndon , Detroit, MI
Farwell Recreation Center, 2711 Outer Dr E, Detroit, MI
Patton Community Center, 2301 Woodmere St, Detroit, MI
Joseph Walker Williams Center, 8431 Rosa Parks Blvd., Detroit, MI

markup.content: To Find out more about the food programs available please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus Resources page.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus Resources page.
Groceries for Families

While Detroit area grocery stores are restocking their shelves regularly, The City of Detroit is also working with Gleaners to provide alternative sites where families can get groceries.  Starting this week, Gleaners added two additional sites with more to come online soon. Gleaners will provide two weeks of groceries to families with children at four Recreation Centers:

content.content: Roberto Clemente Recreation Center: 2631 Bagley 2:30 PM – 5:30 PM, Every other Wednesday started March 25
Heilmann Recreation Center: 13200 Fenelon 2:30 PM – 5:30 PM, Every other Thursday starting March 26
Coleman A. Young Recreation Center: 2751 Robert Bradby Drive 1:30 – 4:30 PM, Every other Saturday starting March 28
Butzel Family Center: 7737 Kercheval 9:00 am – 12:00 PM, Every other Monday starting March 3

markup.content: To Find out more about the food programs available please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus Resources page.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus Resources page.

Detroiters who need their water turned on can sign up for DWSD's Water Restart Plan. If you sign up before April 9, you don't have to put any money down. The State of Michigan will cover it for you! Just call 313-386-9727 to begin the restart. Since the Water Restart Plan was announced on March 9, more than 1,400 Detroit households have taken advantage of it.

During the scheduled turn-on appointment, please make sure someone who is 18 years old or older is home and there is a clear, safe path to the meter. For your safety, an inspection must be done before the water service is turned on. DWSD cannot turn on service without access to the water meter inside your home.
To Find out more about Coronavirus COVID-19 Water Restart Plan please visit the City of Detroit water restart page.
Visit City of Detroit's Water Restart page.
The City of Detroit continues to provide employment assistance & training programs for all their residents.
To Find out more about employment resources please visit Detroitatwork.com.
Visit Detroit at Work site.
Welcome to the COVID-19 FAQs section.
During the assessment, you can refresh the page if you need to start again or close the chat window.
Ready? Let’s get started.
What is your question?

items.name: covid-19-symptoms
items.description: How can I protect myself? Is there a vaccine?
items.text: How can I protect myself? Is there a vaccine?

items.name: covid-19-symptoms
items.description: What to do it you've traveled to an affected area?
items.text: What to do it you've traveled to an affected area?

items.name: covid-19-symptoms
items.description: What should I do if I suspect I have COVID-19?
items.text: What should I do if I suspect I have COVID-19?

items.name: covid-19-symptoms
items.description: Where can I go to get tested for COVID-19?
items.text: Where can I go to get tested for COVID-19?

markup.content: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a respiratory illness that can spread from person to person. The virus that causes COVID-19 is a novel coronavirus that was first identified during an investigation into an outbreak in Wuhan, China.
For more information visit the City of Detroit coronavirus page.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus page.

Reported illnesses have ranged from mild symptoms to severe illness and death for confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases. The following symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure. Call your doctor if you develop symptoms, and have been in close contact with a person known to have COVID-19 or have recently traveled to another country.

content.content: Fever
Cough
Shortness of breath

markup.content: Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus Information page to learn more.
If you are experiencing any symptoms please contact your doctor.
If you don't have a doctor or are uninsured. Please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus page to find a doctor near you.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus Doctor page to learn more.
There is currently no vaccine to protect against COVID-19. The best way to prevent infection is to take everyday preventive actions such as:

content.content: Wash your hands with soap and water for 20+ seconds
Use hand sanitizer with 60% alcohol
Avoid close personal contact with others, such as shaking hands
Practice social distancing by keeping 6 feet from other individuals
Avoid crowded, public spaces
Avoid touching your face
Avoid contact with those who are sick or may be sick
Cancel non-essential travel (both foreign and domestic)
Clean all high-touch surfaces frequently

markup.content: For more information visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus page.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus page.
There is no specific antiviral treatment for COVID-19. People with COVID-19 can seek medical care to help relieve symptoms.
If you have need to get tested please visit the City of Detroit Drive Thru page.
Visit Drive Thru page.
Seek medical advice – Call ahead before you go to a doctor’s office or emergency room. Tell them about your recent travel and your symptoms.
Avoid contact with others.
Not travel on public transportation while sick.
If you don't have a doctor or are uninsured. Please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus page to find a doctor near you.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus Doctor page.
Yes. Most individuals with the virus will recover at home. As of March 14, 72,000 individuals have recovered from COVID-19.
Health experts are still learning the details regarding how COVID-19 spreads. Transmission most likely occurs through:

content.content: The air by coughing and sneezing
Close personal contact
Touching an object/surface with the virus on it and then touching your eyes, nose or mouth
The CDC reports that COVID-19 may survive on various surfaces for hours to days, which is why cleaning all high-touch surfaces is recommended daily.

markup.content: If you want to learn more about the virus. Please visit the City of Detroit Coronavirus page to find out more.
Visit City of Detroit's Coronavirus page.
Older adults, nursing home residents, healthcare professionals, immunocompromised individuals, and people with chronic medical conditions such as diabetes, lung disease or a heart condition.
If you are feeling sick please stay at home and call your primary care doctor or local hospital hotline.
If you have a fever and a cough AND are experiencing any of the following go immediately to the emergency department or call 911 for EMS:

content.content: Difficulty breathing
Confusion
Weakness
Chest pain

markup.content: If you have a cough and no fever or are concerned that you may have been exposed to someone who has been diagnosed with COVID-19:

content.content: Contact your primary care physician by phone (don’t go unannounced) or
Seek a telemedicine evaluation or
Visit an urgent care center or
Contact a regional hotline or
Visit a drive-through screening site

markup.content: If you have a cough WITHOUT difficulty breathing AND no chronic medical conditions*

content.content: Drink fluids
Take over the counter remedies for fever and mild discomfort (e.g., Tylenol)
Stay at home and try and stay at least six feet away from others without symptoms

markup.content: If you have need to get tested please visit the City of Detroit Drive Thru page.
Visit Drive Thru page.
Ascension Southeast Michigan Hospitals

Ascension Michigan ministries have established COVID-19 triage areas near all emergency departments. This includes: Ascension Macomb-Oakland, Warren Campus, Ascension Macomb-Oakland in Madison Heights, Ascension St. John Hospital, Ascension River District, Ascension Providence Rochester Hospital, Ascension Providence Novi Hospital and Ascension Providence Southfield Hospital.
Visit Website
Beaumont Health
Curbside Screening Sites:

content.content: Drink fluids
Dearborn, Royal Oak, Troy: 6 a.m. - 2 a.m.
Grosse Pointe, Farmington Hills, Taylor, Trenton and Wayne: 10 a.m. – 10 p.m.

markup.content: Visit Website
Detroit Medical Center
Hotline: 1-888-DMC-3370
Seven days a week, 5 p.m. – 8 a.m.
Henry Ford Hospital
Monday – Friday, 8 a.m. – 5 p.m.

Screening Site: Henry Ford Allegiance Health, Monday – Sunday, 8 a.m. – 8 p.m. Location is on the surface lot of One Jackson Square, 100 E. Michigan Avenue in Jackson. One person, one vehicle being tested. People are required to call 313–874–7500 to schedule an appointment at the screening site. This is only for people who have symptoms of fever, dry cough and shortness of breath.
McLaren Macomb Hospital

content.content: Drive-up screening tent, 7 a.m. - 7 p.m. for patients already experiencing symptoms (cough, fever, shortness of breath)
Do not need appointment but will be seen in the order of arrival

markup.content: Visit Website
Michigan Medicine
Visit Website
St. Joseph Mercy

content.content: St. Joseph Mercy Ann Arbor. Walk-in tents available for drop-in screening, 11a.m. - 11 p.m., hours subject to change
St. Mary Mercy Livonia. Drive up screening, 10 a.m. – 6 p.m., hours subject to change
